persona.name: Walter Ray McCullough

occupation.title: Retired Farmer
occupation.description: Walter spent most of his adult life running a small family farm, raising soybeans, corn, and a few head of cattle. He managed all aspects of the operation, from planting and harvesting to equipment maintenance and bookkeeping. After his wife passed away, he scaled back operations, eventually leasing most of the land to a neighbor. He still tends a large vegetable garden and keeps a few chickens for eggs. Walter is known locally for his practical knowledge of farming, his willingness to help neighbors with repairs, and his deep roots in the community. He never worked for a large company, preferring the independence of self-employment, though this often meant financial uncertainty.

persona.residence: Rural outskirts of Meridian, Mississippi, USA
persona.education: Completed high school at a small rural school in Lauderdale County, Mississippi, graduating in 1965. No further formal education. Learned practical skills on the family farm from a young age, including animal husbandry, crop rotation, and basic machinery repair. Attended Sunday school and Bible study regularly throughout youth and adulthood, which provided additional informal education in religious and moral instruction.
long_term_goals: To maintain independence and live out his days on his own land, avoiding nursing homes or assisted living facilities.
To keep his health stable enough to continue light outdoor activities, especially jogging and fishing.
To leave the family property in good order for his children and grandchildren.
To remain active in his church community and continue attending Sunday services as long as possible.
To avoid being a financial or emotional burden to his family.
To see his grandchildren grow up with strong values and a respect for tradition.
To keep his mind sharp and avoid cognitive decline.
To be remembered as a hard-working, honest, and God-fearing man.
persona.style: Walter speaks with a slow, deliberate Southern drawl, using colloquial expressions and idioms common in rural Mississippi. He addresses most people as 'sir' or 'ma'am,' especially those he doesn't know well. His manner is reserved and polite, but he can be blunt when discussing topics he feels strongly about. He avoids small talk with strangers, preferring meaningful conversation with family or close friends. He dresses simply: faded jeans, flannel shirts, and well-worn work boots, even when jogging (he changes into old sneakers for that). He wears a battered baseball cap most days. Walter is uncomfortable with technology, rarely uses a cell phone, and prefers face-to-face interactions. He is slow to trust outsiders and values privacy. His body language is restrained; he rarely gestures broadly, and his posture is slightly stooped from years of physical labor.

other_facts: Walter was born in 1947 on the same land he lives on today.
He is the third generation to farm the property, which was originally purchased by his grandfather after World War I.
He met his wife, Martha Sue, at a church picnic in 1967; they married the following year.
Walter was drafted for Vietnam but was medically deferred due to a childhood injury.
He has never traveled outside the Deep South, except for a brief trip to Nashville for a cousin's wedding.
Walter's father died young, so he took over the farm at age 19.
He has a faded tattoo of a cross on his forearm, done by a friend in his youth.
Walter once won a blue ribbon for his tomatoes at the county fair.
He keeps a box of old family photographs and letters in his closet.
Walter's favorite hymn is 'How Great Thou Art.'
He has a deep fear of losing his independence and being forced into a nursing home.
Walter's house is filled with mementos: his wife's quilt, his father's pocketknife, his son's childhood baseball glove.
He has never owned a credit card, preferring to pay cash for everything.
Walter's only luxury is a secondhand recliner, bought after his wife passed.
He once rescued a neighbor's cow during a flood, earning local praise.
Walter is known for his stubborn refusal to use a cell phone, though his daughter insists he keep one for emergencies.
He has a small, hand-painted sign at the end of his driveway: 'McCullough Farm, Est. 1921.'
Walter's favorite meal is fried catfish with hush puppies, though he rarely indulges due to health.
He keeps a weathered American flag on his porch, raising and lowering it daily.
Walter has a habit of humming hymns while working.
He once broke his arm falling from a ladder but finished the day's chores before seeking help.
Walter's only vacation was a camping trip to the Smoky Mountains in 1978.
He has a deep distrust of banks, keeping most savings in a lockbox at home.
Walter's eyesight is failing, but he refuses to stop driving short distances.
He has a scar on his left hand from a childhood accident with a hay baler.
Walter's favorite season is fall, when the air is cool and the leaves turn.
He has never learned to swim, despite living near several creeks.
Walter's favorite saying is, 'If it ain't broke, don't fix it.'
He once considered selling the farm but couldn't bear the thought of leaving.
Walter's greatest regret is not spending more time with his children when they were young.
He keeps a journal, mostly to record weather patterns and garden yields.
Walter's faith was shaken after his wife's death, but he found comfort in scripture.
He has a small, hand-carved cross that he carries in his pocket.
Walter's favorite TV show is 'The Andy Griffith Show.'
He has never flown in an airplane.
Walter's hands are rough and calloused, a testament to decades of hard work.
He sometimes talks to his late wife when alone in the house.
Walter's biggest fear is outliving his usefulness.
He has a deep sense of pride in his family's history and land.
